children.text: Okay, I need to translate this Java code into Fortran.
children.label: language_mapping

children.text: Let me start by understanding what the Java code does.
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: The main part reads an integer n, then reads n integers into a list.
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text: If n is 1, it just prints that integer. Otherwise, it sorts the list.
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text: If the last element is zero, it prints zero.
children.label: mental_execution

children.text: Then, there's a loop where it repeatedly applies a function 'func' to the list until there's only one element left, which is the answer.
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: The 'func' function processes the list by first removing any zeros.
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: It finds the minimum non-zero value and then replaces each element with the remainder when divided by this minimum.
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text: If any element becomes 1, it immediately prints 1 and exits. Then it sorts the list again.
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: If any of them becomes 1, exit with 1. Then sort.
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text: If any of them becomes 1, output 1 and exit. But in the Java code, during the loop through the array elements, when a.get(i) is zero, it's removed.
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: If any element becomes 1, exit.
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text: Wait, in the Java code, during the 'func' method, elements are removed if they are zero.
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: Then, if n is 1, output the single element.
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text: Similarly, check if the maximum element (after sorting) is zero, output zero. Then, the loop.
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text: The main challenge is the 'func' function. Let's see.
children.label: code_analysis

children.text:
In 'func', the process is:

- Remove all zeros. Wait, no.
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: Looking at the Java code: in the loop over a.size(), if a.get(i) is zero, remove it.
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: Then, for the first non-zero element, set that as min.
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text: Then, for other elements, compute a mod min.
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text: Then, all other elements are set to their remainder modulo this min.
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text: Then, for the subsequent elements, subtract their mod with min.
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text: Then, for the remaining elements, set them to mod min.
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text:
Then, after processing all elements, the array is sorted again. So the process is:

1. Remove all zeros.
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text: 2. Find the minimum value (which is the first element after sorting and removing zeros). 3.
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text: For all other elements, compute mod min. If any of these is 1, exit.
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text: 4. Remove any zeros resulting from the mod operation. 5. Sort the array again. So in Fortran, we can model this with an array. Let's think step by step.
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text: First, when translating 'func', the input is an array. Let's make a copy. Then, process it. But in Fortran, arrays are not as dynamic as Java's ArrayLists. So perhaps, for each step, we can create a new array with the non-zero elements, then compute the mod with the minimum, then remove any zeros, then sort again.
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text: Alternatively, use a list structure, but Fortran doesn't have built-in lists. So perhaps use an allocatable array that we resize as needed.
children.label: language_mapping

children.text: First, handling dynamic arrays.
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text: Fortran uses allocatable arrays, which can be dynamically resized. So for each step, the array can be manipulated. But in Fortran, you can't just remove elements from an array.
children.label: code_analysis

children.text:
You need to create a new array with the desired elements. So for example, to remove zeros from an array:

function remove_zeros(arr) result(res)
   integer, intent(in) :: arr(:)
   integer, allocatable :: res(:)
   integer :: i, cnt
   cnt = count(arr /= 0)
   allocate(res(cnt)) cnt = 0 do i = 1, size(arr)
      if (arr(i) /= 0) then
         cnt = cnt + 1
         res(cnt) = arr(i)
      end if
   end do
end function remove_zeros

Similarly, when building the new array C, which includes min_val and the mod_vals (including zeros), then sorting.
children.label: code_analysis

children.text:
So, the func function in Fortran would be:

function func(A) result(res)
children.label: language_mapping

children.text:
integer, allocatable :: res(:)
   integer, intent(in) :: A(:)
   integer, allocatable :: B(:), C(:)
   integer :: min_val, mod_val, i

   B = remove_zeros(A)
   if (size(B) == 0) then
      allocate(res(0)) return
   end if

   min_val = B(1)
   allocate(C(size(B)))  !
children.label: code_analysis

children.text:
min_val + mod_vals (B(2:))
   C(1) = min_val
   do i = 2, size(B)
      mod_val = mod(B(i), min_val)
      if (mod_val == 1) then
         print *, 1
         stop
      end if
      C(i) = mod_val
   end do

   !
children.label: code_analysis

children.text:
Now, include all elements of C (including zeros)
   ! Then sort and return
   call sort_array(C)
   res = C
end function func

But wait, the size of B is variable.

children.text: Now, implementing the remove_zeros function, the sort function, etc.
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text: Fortran has a built-in 'sort' function?
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: No, but you can use the intrinsic 'sort' function if available, or implement a simple one.
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: Alternatively, for sorting, use the 'sort' function from the intrinsic module, but I think Fortran's standard library doesn't have a sort function. So need to implement a simple one.
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text: Alternatively, in the code, after building an array, sort it.
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text: So, implement a bubble sort or similar. But for small arrays, that's acceptable. But since the original code uses Java's Collections.sort, which is a stable sort, but the exact algorithm isn't important here. So in Fortran, we can use a simple sorting subroutine.
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text: Alternatively, use an interface to the quicksort algorithm. But for the purposes of this code, perhaps write a simple sort function.
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text:
So, a subroutine that sorts an array in ascending order. subroutine sort_array(arr)
   integer, intent(inout) :: arr(:)
   integer :: i, j, temp
   do i = 1, size(arr) do j = i+1, size(arr)
         if (arr(j) < arr(i)) then
            temp = arr(i)
            arr(i) = arr(j)
            arr(j) = temp
         end if
      end do
   end do
end subroutine sort_array

This is a simple (inefficient) bubble sort. But for small arrays, it's acceptable. Now, putting it all together. The full Fortran code:

module utils
contains
   function remove_zeros(arr) result(res)
      integer, intent(in) :: arr(:)
      integer, allocatable :: res(:)
      integer :: i, cnt

      cnt = count(arr /= 0)
      allocate(res(cnt)) cnt = 0 do i = 1, size(arr)
         if (arr(i) /= 0) then
            cnt = cnt + 1
            res(cnt) = arr(i)
         end if
      end do
   end function remove_zeros

   subroutine sort_array(arr)
      integer, intent(inout) :: arr(:)
      integer :: i, j, temp do i = 1, size(arr)-1
         do j = i+1, size(arr)
            if (arr(j) < arr(i)) then
               temp = arr(i)
               arr(i) = arr(j)
               arr(j) = temp
            end if
         end do
      end do
   end subroutine sort_array

   function func(A) result(res)
      integer, allocatable :: res(:)
      integer, intent(in) :: A(:)
      integer, allocatable :: B(:), C(:)
      integer :: min_val, mod_val, i, n

      B = remove_zeros(A)
      if (size(B) == 0) then
         allocate(res(0)) return
      end if

      min_val = B(1)
      n = size(B)
      allocate(C(n))
      C(1) = min_val

      do i = 2, n
         mod_val = mod(B(i), min_val)
         if (mod_val == 1) then
            print *, 1
            stop
         end if
         C(i) = mod_val
      end do

      call sort_array(C)
      res = C
   end function func
end module utils

program main
   use utils
   implicit none
   integer :: n, i, ans
   integer, allocatable :: a(:)

   read *, n
   if (n == 1) then
      allocate(a(1))
      read *, a(1)
      print *, a(1)
      stop
   end if

   allocate(a(n))
   read *, (a(i), i=1, n)
   call sort_array(a) if (a(n) == 0) then
      print *, 0
      stop
   end if

   do while (size(a) > 1)
      a = func(a)
   end do

   print *, a(1)

end program main

function remove_zeros(arr) result(res)
   integer, intent(in) :: arr(:)
   integer, allocatable :: res(:)
   integer :: i, cnt
   cnt = count(arr /= 0)
   allocate(res(cnt))
   cnt = 0
   do i = 1, size(arr)
      if (arr(i) /= 0) then
         cnt = cnt + 1
         res(cnt) = arr(i)
      end if
   end do
end function remove_zeros

So, a subroutine that sorts an array in ascending order.

subroutine sort_array(arr)
   integer, intent(inout) :: arr(:)
   integer :: i, j, temp
   do i = 1, size(arr)
      do j = i+1, size(arr)
         if (arr(j) < arr(i)) then
            temp = arr(i)
            arr(i) = arr(j)
            arr(j) = temp
         end if
      end do
   end do
end subroutine sort_array

This is a simple (inefficient) bubble sort. But for small arrays, it's acceptable.

Now, putting it all together.

The full Fortran code:

module utils
contains
   function remove_zeros(arr) result(res)
      integer, intent(in) :: arr(:)
      integer, allocatable :: res(:)
      integer :: i, cnt

      cnt = count(arr /= 0)
      allocate(res(cnt))
      cnt = 0
      do i = 1, size(arr)
         if (arr(i) /= 0) then
            cnt = cnt + 1
            res(cnt) = arr(i)
         end if
      end do
   end function remove_zeros

   subroutine sort_array(arr)
      integer, intent(inout) :: arr(:)
      integer :: i, j, temp
      do i = 1, size(arr)-1
         do j = i+1, size(arr)
            if (arr(j) < arr(i)) then
               temp = arr(i)
               arr(i) = arr(j)
               arr(j) = temp
            end if
         end do
      end do
   end subroutine sort_array

   function func(A) result(res)
      integer, allocatable :: res(:)
      integer, intent(in) :: A(:)
      integer, allocatable :: B(:), C(:)
      integer :: min_val, mod_val, i, n

      B = remove_zeros(A)
      if (size(B) == 0) then
         allocate(res(0))
         return
      end if

      min_val = B(1)
      n = size(B)
      allocate(C(n))
      C(1) = min_val

      do i = 2, n
         mod_val = mod(B(i), min_val)
         if (mod_val == 1) then
            print *, 1
            stop
         end if
         C(i) = mod_val
      end do

      call sort_array(C)
      res = C
   end function func
end module utils

program main
   use utils
   implicit none
   integer :: n, i, ans
   integer, allocatable :: a(:)

   read *, n
   if (n == 1) then
      allocate(a(1))
      read *, a(1)
      print *, a(1)
      stop
   end if

   allocate(a(n))
   read *, (a(i), i=1, n)
   call sort_array(a)

   if (a(n) == 0) then
      print *, 0
      stop
   end if

   do while (size(a) > 1)
      a = func(a)
   end do

   print *, a(1)

end program main
